channel.title: Obsidian Mindmap
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian

item.title: aspirations
item.description:
aspire /əˈspʌɪə/ late Middle English: from French aspirer or Latin aspirare, from ad- ‘to’ + spirare ‘breathe’. direct one's hopes or ambitions towards achieving something. rise high; tower.
Some of my aspirations are listed on the welcome page, enough for now...

item.title: guides
item.description:
guide
/ɡʌɪd/ late Middle English: from Old French guide (noun), guider (verb), of Germanic origin; related to wit2. One who shows the way by leading, directing, or advising. One who serves as a model for others, as in a course of conduct. To direct the course of; steer.
inspirations (divine guidance)
guiding principles
guiding methods

item.title: welcome
item.description:
/ˈwɛlkəm/ Old English wilcuma ‘a person whose coming is pleasing’, wilcumian (verb), from wil- ‘desire, pleasure’ + cuman ‘come’. The first element was later changed to wel- ‘well’, influenced by Old French bien venu or Old Norse velkominn . Received with pleasure and hospitality into one's company or home. The state of being welcome. Welcome to my mind garden experiment. It is in the form of a digital garden.
Some of my aspirations:
understanding The Universe (Reality, The World, whatever you wanna call it), because I am in awe even just at the mere phenomenon of existence, life, consciousness and want to feel at home and be fully connected both 'intellectually' and 'spiritually' finding ways to practically apply Christopher Alexander's theories found in The Nature of Order, into everyday life Living Structure 15 Properties Structure Preserving Transformations because I believe these ways of seeing the World are more correct, and will superseded the current, predominantly mechanistic worldview realizing The Glass Bead Game (described in Hermann Hesse's book of the same name), because in my interpretation, conception, it would be one of the highest forms of Communication, Understanding, Art and honestly it would be a super fun to experience. I believe there may be People who suffer, because this instrument has not yet been created and therefore cannot express themselves to the highest degree (just imagine, if the piano was not there in the time of Mozart) making improvements and leaving The World a better place (one where I'd like to be constantly re-born) ... Some of my beliefs: Ever since I read Christopher Alexander's The Nature of Order, I completely ascribe to the view, that every part of space has a degree of Life (as opposed to segregating 'living' and 'dead' things) and Wholeness (aka. Health) and that it is our duty and responsibility to learn how this structure emerges in Nature so that we can be an extension of Structure Preserving Process, the Structure Enhancing Process. ...
Now that we put some aspirations into words, what will be our guides?
inspirations (divine guidance)
guiding principles
guiding methods About me. I'm a: Human Person Child Son Father Husband Philosopher Searcher Pisces Male Generation Y Millennial Digital Native Polyglot Origamist

item.title: aspire
item.description: /əˈspʌɪə/late Middle English: from French aspirer or Latin aspirare, from ad- ‘to’ + spirare ‘breathe’. verb direct one's hopes or ambitions towards achieving something. rise high; tower. To have a great ambition or ultimate goal; desire strongly. To strive toward an end or condition. Archaic To rise high; move upwards. To breathe to or into.

item.title: index
item.description:
/ˈɪndɛks/ late Middle English: from Latin index, indic- ‘forefinger, informer, sign’, from in- ‘towards’ + a second element related to dicere ‘say’ or dicare ‘make known’; compare with indicate. The original sense ‘index finger’ (with which one points), came to mean ‘pointer’ (late 16th century), and figuratively something that serves to point to a fact or conclusion; hence a list of topics in a book (‘pointing’ to their location).
This is the main page, because every site needs one.
welcome
digital garden
goals and aspirations
guides
inspirations
guiding principles
guiding methods
words

item.title: inspirations
item.description:
inspiration /ɪnspɪˈreɪʃ(ə)n/ Origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘divine guidance’): via Old French from late Latin inspiratio(n- ), from the verb inspirare (see inspire). Definitions: the process of being mentally stimulated to do or feel something, especially to do something creative. the quality of being inspired. a sudden brilliant or timely idea. the drawing in of breath; inhalation. Without providing any specific context at the moment, here are some things I consider inspirational. Nature Cosmos Flowers Beauty Common Sense Systems Theory Gaia Rhizome Structure Preserving Transformations Pattern Theory 15 Properties (of space) Gestalt Christopher Alexander Isaac Asimov Jonathan Blow (Jon Blow) Brian Moriarty Stanislaw Lem Jeremy England Alan Watts
Christopher Alexander: Patterns in Architecture (1996) - link
Jonathan Blow: Preventing the Collapse of Civilization (2019) - link
Jonathan Blow: Video Games and the Human Condition (2010) - link Alan Watts: Do You Do It or Does It Do You? Alexander Rose: The Data of Long-Lived Institutions — Alexander Rose at The Interval Bret Viktor: Drawing Dynamic Visualizations Bret Viktor: Media for the Unthinkable Bret Viktor: The Humane Representation of Thought Christopher Alexander Notes on the Synthesis of Form A Pattern Language The Nature of Order: An Essay on the Art of Building and the Nature of the Universe The Phenomenon of Life The Process of Creating Life A Vision of a Living World The Luminous Ground Keith Houston The BOOK Robert Pirsig Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance Tao Te Ching Italo Calvino Invisible Cities Isaac Asimov Foundation Braid (2008) The Witness (2016) Outer Wilds (2019) Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice (2019) Elden Ring (2022)

item.title: digital garden
item.description:
garden
/ˈɡɑːdn/ Middle English: from Old Northern French gardin, variant of Old French jardin, of Germanic origin; related to yard2. cultivate or work in a garden. a piece of ground adjoining a house, in which grass, flowers, and shrubs may be grown. ornamental grounds laid out for public enjoyment and recreation. a large public hall. I decided to try this form of publishing as it aligns the most with my way of thinking (at the moment).It's purpose is to use it as a means of documenting, publishing (sharing) my thinking about a couple of initiatives I am trying to realize.I hope it will help to force me to think very carefully about the ideas I am trying to develop, about the words I use, and the thoughts I publish.

item.title: words
item.description:
word /wəːd/ Old English word, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch woord and German Wort, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin verbum ‘word’. a command, password, or signal. something spoken or written; a remark or statement. even the smallest amount of something spoken or written. one's account of the truth, especially when it differs from that of another person. a basic unit of data in a computer, typically 16 or 32 bits long.
assume
assumption
erudition
garden
guide
index
inspiration
method
page
principle
site
welcome
word
word (template, lite)
word (template)

item.title: guiding principles
item.description: principle /ˈprɪn(t)sɪpl/ late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin principium ‘source’, principia (plural) ‘foundations’, from princeps, princip- ‘first, chief’. a rule or belief governing one's behaviour. morally correct behaviour and attitudes. a fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief or behaviour or for a chain of reasoning. a fundamental source or basis of something. a fundamental quality determining the nature of something. A guiding principle is a fundamental, core belief or value that directs an individual's or organization's decisions, behaviors, and actions. These principles serve as an internal compass, providing a framework for consistency, ethics, and strategic direction regardless of changing circumstances. Behind every action, activity, there seems to be a guiding principle, process, a source, even if we don't realize or cannot articulate them. But being aware can provide a powerful framework.

item.title: garden
item.description: /ˈɡɑːdn/Middle English: from Old Northern French gardin, variant of Old French jardin, of Germanic origin; related to yard2. cultivate or work in a garden. a piece of ground adjoining a house, in which grass, flowers, and shrubs may be grown. ornamental grounds laid out for public enjoyment and recreation. a large public hall.

item.title: word
item.description: /wəːd/Old English word, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch woord and German Wort, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin verbum ‘word’.Definitions: verb express (something spoken or written) in particular words. Noun a command, password, or signal. something spoken or written; a remark or statement. even the smallest amount of something spoken or written. one's account of the truth, especially when it differs from that of another person. a basic unit of data in a computer, typically 16 or 32 bits long.

item.title: site
item.description: /sʌɪt/late Middle English (as a noun): from Anglo-Norman French, or from Latin situs ‘local position’. The verb dates from the late 16th century.Definitions: verb fix or build (something) in a particular place. Noun an area of ground on which a town, building, or monument is constructed. a place where a particular event or activity is occurring or has occurred. short for 'building site'. short for campsite or caravan site. a website.

item.title: page
item.description: /peɪdʒ/late 15th century: from French, from Latin pagina, from pangere ‘fasten’.Definitions: verb look through the pages of (a book, magazine, etc.). Computing move through and display (text) one page at a time. divide (a piece of software or data) into sections, keeping the most frequently accessed in main memory and storing the rest in virtual memory. Noun the material written or printed on a page. a page of a newspaper or magazine set aside for a particular topic. Computing a section of stored data, especially that which can be displayed on a screen at one time. a significant event or period considered as a part of a longer history. Similar: folio sheet side leaf period stage phase

item.title: assumption
item.description: /əˈsʌm(p)ʃn/From Middle English assumpcioun, from Medieval Latin assumptio ("a taking up (into heaven)") and Latin assumption ("a taking up, adoption, the minor proposition of a syllogism"); see assume. noun a thing that is accepted as true or as certain to happen, without proof. the action of taking on power or responsibility. verb Middle English assumpcion, from Latin assūmptiō__, assūmptiōn-, adoption, from assūmptus, past participle of assūmere, to adopt; see assume.Middle English (in assumption(sense 3 of the noun)): from Old French asompsion or Latin assumptio(n- ), from the verb assumere (see assume)

item.title: assume
item.description: /əˈsjuːm/late Middle English: from Latin assumere, from ad- ‘towards’ + sumere ‘take’. verb suppose to be the case, without proof. take or begin to have (power or responsibility). begin to have (a specified quality, appearance, or extent). take on or adopt (a manner or identity), sometimes falsely. Middle English assumen, from Latin assūmere : ad-, ad- + sūmere, to take; see em- in Indo-European roots.From Latin assūmō ("accept, take"), from ad- ("to, towards, at") + sūmō ("take up, assume").

item.title: method
item.description: /ˈmɛθəd/ late Middle English (in the sense ‘prescribed medical treatment for a disease’): via Latin from Greek methodos ‘pursuit of knowledge’, from meta- (expressing development) + hodos ‘way’.Definitions: a particular procedure for accomplishing or approaching something, especially a systematic or established one. the quality of being well organized and systematic in thought or action

item.title: index
item.description: /ˈɪndɛks/late Middle English: from Latin index, indic- ‘forefinger, informer, sign’, from in- ‘towards’ + a second element related to dicere ‘say’ or dicare ‘make known’; compare with indicate. The original sense ‘index finger’ (with which one points), came to mean ‘pointer’ (late 16th century), and figuratively something that serves to point to a fact or conclusion; hence a list of topics in a book (‘pointing’ to their location). noun Something that serves to guide, point out, or otherwise facilitate reference, especially. An alphabetized list of names, places, and subjects treated in a printed work, giving the page or pages on which each item is mentioned. Middle English, forefinger, from Latin; see deik- in Indo-European roots.From Latin index ("a discoverer, informer, spy; of things, an indicator, the forefinger, a title, superscription"), from indicō ("point out, show"); see indicate.

item.title: guide
item.description:
/ɡʌɪd/late Middle English: from Old French guide (noun), guider (verb), of Germanic origin; related to wit2. verb show or indicate the way to (someone). direct the motion or positioning of (something). Noun One who shows the way by leading, directing, or advising. One who serves as a model for others, as in a course of conduct.
https://wordnik.com/words/guide

item.title: guiding methods
item.description:
method /ˈmɛθəd/ noun Origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘prescribed medical treatment for a disease’): via Latin from Greek methodos ‘pursuit of knowledge’, from meta- (expressing development) + hodos ‘way’. Definitions: a particular procedure for accomplishing or approaching something, especially a systematic or established one. the quality of being well organized and systematic in thought or action Disclaimer: this 'list' will change massively as we go on, as the new things we learn and discover using these guiding methods will recursively change the process itself. The list here will have the TLDR version with more details in the full articles.As a first, self recursive guiding method let's have:
Keep in mind, check and develop the guiding methods you have We have used words, English words to articulate, note and document this first guiding principle. If the words make sense to you, good, it means we made an intelligible sentence. Words and writing are a very very powerful tool.
Inspect your base assumptions
We are not starting everything from 0, all the time. Whatever we do, whenever we communicate we make a number (innumerable) assumptions. This has an important function to keep things efficient, but there can be disadvantages, and in this case serious ones. But what exactly does the word, assumption mean?
Study the meaning of the words A lot can be learned by reading the dictionary entry of a word. The Contexts it is used in, it's Relateds, Synonyms, etc., it's Etymology (origin) can reveal new aspects and insights that will make thinking and documentation more effective and precise.
Make the methods actionable They are useful as text, but they will come alive as code. For example: To keep in mind the guiding principles, set up reminders and other mechanisms similar for the base assumptions create a template for words the words you use Of course this has to be elaborated much more to become robust. But let's start by defining some words that we have used so far.
index
welcome
guide
assume
assumption

item.title: erudition
item.description: noun Deep, extensive learning. synonym: knowledge. Learning; scholarship; knowledge gained by study or from books and instruction; particularly, learning in literature, history, antiquities, and languages, as distinct from knowledge of the mathematical and physical sciences. The act of instructing; the result of thorough instruction; the state of being erudite or learned; the acquisitions gained by extensive reading or study; particularly, learning in literature or criticism, as distinct from the sciences; scholarship. Profound knowledge, especially that based on learning and scholarship. From Latin eruditio ("an instructing, learning, erudition"), from erudire ("to instruct, educate, cultivate", literally "free from rudeness"), from e ("out") + rudis ("rude").The word "erudition" comes from the Latin eruditio, meaning "learning," which is a noun from the verb erudire, meaning "to instruct" or "to educate". This Latin verb is a compound of e- ("out") and rudis ("rude," "unskilled," or "rough"), so erudire literally meant "to free from rudeness". Therefore, erudition is the result of being "taken out of a rough or uncultivated state" through a process of education and learning.  Latin roots: erudire = e- ("out") + rudis ("rough," "unskilled"). Literal meaning: "To free from rudeness" or "to remove coarseness". Figurative meaning: The process of educating or instructing someone, leading them from a state of being "rough" or unlearned to one of polished and extensive knowledge. Modern usage: The noun "erudition" refers to the deep, scholarly knowledge that results from this process.

item.title: inspiration
item.description: /ɪnspɪˈreɪʃ(ə)n/Origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘divine guidance’): via Old French from late Latin inspiratio(n- ), from the verb inspirare (see inspire).Definitions: the process of being mentally stimulated to do or feel something, especially to do something creative. the quality of being inspired. a sudden brilliant or timely idea. the drawing in of breath; inhalation. Similar words: creativity inventiveness innovation imagination stimulus motivation inhalation revelation brainwave

item.title: principle
item.description: /ˈprɪn(t)sɪpl/late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin principium ‘source’, principia (plural) ‘foundations’, from princeps, princip- ‘first, chief’.Definitions: a rule or belief governing one's behaviour. morally correct behaviour and attitudes. a fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief or behaviour or for a chain of reasoning. a fundamental source or basis of something. a fundamental quality determining the nature of something.

item.title: welcome
item.description: /ˈwɛlkəm/ adjective Received with pleasure and hospitality into one's company or home. Giving pleasure or satisfaction; agreeable or gratifying. noun A cordial greeting or hospitable reception given to an arriving person. A reception upon arrival. The state of being welcome. verb To greet, receive, or entertain (another or others) cordially or hospitably. interjection Used to greet cordially a visitor or recent arrival. Old English wilcuma ‘a person whose coming is pleasing’, wilcumian (verb), from wil- ‘desire, pleasure’ + cuman ‘come’. The first element was later changed to wel- ‘well’, influenced by Old French bien venu or Old Norse velkominn .Middle English, alteration (influenced by wel, well) of Old English wilcuma, welcome guest, welcome; see gwā- in Indo-European roots.

item.title: Study the meaning of the words
item.description: Once we learn a language, we can use the words, the main building blocks of a sentence, effortlessly. But there is often much more to a word than what we know on the surface level.Human language is said to be 'messy' and ambiguous, context dependent, and not nearly as 'precise' as a formal language, like a programming language. The conversation with a friend, or this page will not crash if I make a semantic (meaning) or syntax (grammatical) error. Still, a lot can be learned by reading the dictionary entry of a word. A lot of words have their original roots in Latin and Greek.Studying these aspects of the words can provide new, useful insights, improve our mastery of them, etc.www.wordnik.com
item.guid: guides/guiding methods/Study the meaning of the words.md

item.title: guiding principles
item.description:
A guiding principle is a fundamental, core belief or value that directs an individual's or organization's decisions, behaviors, and actions. These principles serve as an internal compass, providing a framework for consistency, ethics, and strategic direction regardless of changing circumstances. Behind every action, activity, there seems to be a guiding principle or process, even if we don't realize or cannot articulate them. But being aware can provide a powerful framework.Disclaimer: this 'list' will change massively as we go on, as the new things we learn and discover using these guiding principles will recursively change the process itself. The list here will have the TLDR version with more details in the full articles.As a first, self recursive guiding principle let's have: Keep in mind, check and develop the guiding principles you have We have used words, English words to articulate, note and document this first guiding principle. If the words make sense to you, good, it means we made an intelligible sentence. Words and writing are a very very powerful tool.
Inspect your base assumptions
We are not starting everything from 0, all the time. Whatever we do, whenever we communicate we make a number (innumerable) assumptions. This has an important function to keep things efficient, but there can be disadvantages, and in this case serious ones. But what exactly does the word, assumption mean?
Study the meaning of the words A lot can be learned by reading the dictionary entry of a word. The Contexts it is used in, it's Relateds, Synonyms, etc., it's Etymology (origin) can reveal new aspects and insights that will make thinking and documentation more effective and precise.
Make the principles actionable They are useful as text, but they will come alive as code. For example: To keep in mind the guiding principles, set up reminders and other mechanisms similar for the base assumptions create a template for words the words you use Of course this has to be elaborated much more to become robust. But let's start by defining some words that we have used so far.
